The Presidency
-Nobody wins in a game like this," said Dean Robert
Strider yesterday, and, indeed, his sober words should temper
any gleeful celebration of the president's resignation. There is
the initial flush of victory when it is learned that the man so
long fought, so long battered about by the undergraduate
community, so many times despised for his diplomatic
ramblings - - that this man has resigned. But then it must be
realized that he was forced out by a senior faculty jealous of
their power and their right to do research unmolested by
either the meddlings of undergraduates or the financial
difficulties of an incompetent president.
Lincoln Gordon had to go. His administration bordered on
the chaotic. His fund-raising, a task he admittedly loathed,
was ineffectual. He had lost the faith of the students two years
ago when he stood on the steps of Homewood House, flustered
and impotent in the face of a mild radical assault. And he lost
the faith of the faculty last December when he told them, yes,
ten per cent of your number are expendable, but no, we can't
cut any administrators. It was a position he tried to reverse too
late.
Lincoln Gordon had to go, and his departure clears the way
for what could be a tremendous improvement in the
University, for imaginative leadership that can lead us
through this tricky period of austerity. The unity
demonstrated by the faculty in this ouster move is a hopeful
sign, for it shows that a group of men who rarely express an
interest outside their esoteric academic fields can come
together with true concern for their University. If that concern
can be fostered, if that awareness of what is best for the school
can be continued, then Hopkins is in for an exciting period of
sustained improvement.
But the danger is grave that the faculty, now that they have
flexed their muscles and proven themselves nearly invincible,
will retreat into their various offices, cotent to let the
University muck itself up again while they resist sorely
needed innovations. They would show that their motive for
ousting Gordon was simply to ensure their dominance in the
University power structure.
If this were to happen, the long - sought - for gains in
undergraduate education could quietly disappear. The
governance issue could once again be reduced to the
mutterings of a few malcontents. The University could cease
to critically examine its role in the problem - ridden society,
and innovative thinking would go the way of concern for the
University, both becoming shadows that had substance only in
the early months of 1971.
It is up to the senior faculty, who led the revolt against
Gordon and have shown that they possess the power, to see
that this does not happen. Men like George Benton, Maurice
Man delbaum and George Owen must no take the initiative and
prevent their colleagues from falling into indifference.
Creative concern and community effort must guide the actions
of the faculty through the choosing of a successor to Lincoln
Gordon. It is only by such efforts that the University can
survive this shock and begin to fulfill the promise it holds.

The Presidency
-Nobody wins in a game like this," said Dean Robert
Strider yesterday, and, indeed, his sober words should temper
any gleeful celebration of the president's resignation. There is
the initial flush of victory when it is learned that the man so
long fought, so long battered about by the undergraduate
community, so many times despised for his diplomatic
ramblings - - that this man has resigned. But then it must be
realized that he was forced out by a senior faculty jealous of
their power and their right to do research unmolested by
either the meddlings of undergraduates or the financial
difficulties of an incompetent president.
Lincoln Gordon had to go. His administration bordered on
the chaotic. His fund-raising, a task he admittedly loathed,
was ineffectual. He had lost the faith of the students two years
ago when he stood on the steps of Homewood House, flustered
and impotent in the face of a mild radical assault. And he lost
the faith of the faculty last December when he told them, yes,
ten per cent of your number are expendable, but no, we can't
cut any administrators. It was a position he tried to reverse too
late.
Lincoln Gordon had to go, and his departure clears the way
for what could be a tremendous improvement in the
University, for imaginative leadership that can lead us
through this tricky period of austerity. The unity
demonstrated by the faculty in this ouster move is a hopeful
sign, for it shows that a group of men who rarely express an
interest outside their esoteric academic fields can come
together with true concern for their University. If that concern
can be fostered, if that awareness of what is best for the school
can be continued, then Hopkins is in for an exciting period of
sustained improvement.
But the danger is grave that the faculty, now that they have
flexed their muscles and proven themselves nearly invincible,
will retreat into their various offices, cotent to let the
University muck itself up again while they resist sorely
needed innovations. They would show that their motive for
ousting Gordon was simply to ensure their dominance in the
University power structure.
If this were to happen, the long - sought - for gains in
undergraduate education could quietly disappear. The
governance issue could once again be reduced to the
mutterings of a few malcontents. The University could cease
to critically examine its role in the problem - ridden society,
and innovative thinking would go the way of concern for the
University, both becoming shadows that had substance only in
the early months of 1971.
It is up to the senior faculty, who led the revolt against
Gordon and have shown that they possess the power, to see
that this does not happen. Men like George Benton, Maurice
Man delbaum and George Owen must no take the initiative and
prevent their colleagues from falling into indifference.
Creative concern and community effort must guide the actions
of the faculty through the choosing of a successor to Lincoln
Gordon. It is only by such efforts that the University can
survive this shock and begin to fulfill the promise it holds.
